blog.name: ships-n-dip
blog.title: A Bisexual Mess
blog.description: If you’re following for consistent content, you’ve come to the wrong place

blog.name: morningmightcomebyaccident
blog.title: a convenient distraction
blog.description:
greywing @ lj
ctrlx/greywing @ AO3
Orphan Black fanfic
By following this blog, you agree to be bombarded by long text posts. Have a good day.

title: Killing Eve 2x02
body:
“Lemon drizzle” made me laugh out loud. Also, they’re really going for different colors in the title card. The teal really really made the screen burn.

… I… like Raymond? Everyone else has underestimated Villanelle and I’m glad the writing wants to show us that Raymond is not here for shit–and from his perspective it’s really the way this needs to be handled. Every previous handler suffered for letting Villanelle act as she wished. I was shocked she called the bailout number and that she got into the car, if only because she saw the cleaners sent to disappear her. Maybe some caution should be in order?

I really enjoyed Eve’s side of this episode, the way her new coworkers stared at her as she started to almost wax rhapsodic about Villanelle, her excitement at being right–there’s a real thrill Eve gets when she’s validated and you get the sense how long she’s been starved of that, of her theories being belittled and her voice unheard. I definitely smiled when she sniped back at Hugo about being interrupted and the small camera moment of solidarity between two women of color. 

Again, the pacing this episode feels slower than it was in S1, partly because I think we sat in one location more in each episode whereas S1 felt like a chase through cities, Villanelle leaving behind bodies and clues and Eve having to sniff them out. Like Villanelle in the hospital and here Villanelle in Julian’s house. I kinda got a thrill that the tables had been turned on Villanelle, who had thought she’d set up this scenario to manipulate this man and it turns out she put herself into a trap. Of course I enjoyed that she wrecked Julian because he himself turned out to be such a creep, but some karma felt deserved here. I understand that’s a problematic thing to say, in the sense of victims should not be held accountable as “asking for it”–but, in this case, Villanelle set out to be the perpetrator of crimes here and ended up the victim of a different, creepier crime. It’s complicated.

Julian himself is an interesting commentary that I haven’t quite wrapped my head around. The fact that the only person who would be willing to help someone like a young, desperate woman would be someone who themselves don’t have the best intentions is a searing indictment on society. Like we, too, the audience question why Julian is being so nice and going out of his way–because who would… unless they were creepy? Both of Emerald Fennell’s episodes have these moments of examining how “normal” citizens move through society–through the social contract, through what is/what isn’t part of social obligation–by calculating risk (and return, as Julian expressly puts into words).

Very glad to see Konstantin just because I really love Kim Bodnia in the role. Also on that note, the actor playing Kenny has such great facial expressions. The panic in his eyes when Eve was telling him what happened in Paris–lol. Also, Eve, way to be a dick to be like: Oh, now you’re withholding information too!

Other random thoughts… Would Eve really not see the Biblical implications of the Apple? I felt like the show really held out hands on that–but also I did think some people aren’t exposed to that canon, so, okay, show, I’ll give it to you. Also quite fascinating that Villanelle and Eve already have enough shorthand references for Villanelle to give Eve little shout outs, like the apple and then the toilet brush. Eve, you didn’t have to sit in bed and use the laptop, you could, y’know, get out of bed. I also kinda like that Niko has more opinions about clothes than Eve does? LOL

Really love the camera not showing us the face of the new assassin. I really, really wanted to see her face and I appreciate the anticipation. Also: I loved her silhouette? She’s not a svelte young woman running around like Villanelle; she’s slipping under the radar by being plain. Love it.

Loved Eve’s little pause hearing the recording of Villanelle yelling, “Eve Polastri, you piece of shit!”

I had a thought about… ah! All the yellow grass! Man, that would not fly with all the SoCal housing associations.

Yup, all my first impressions. I wasn’t blown away again, but still intrigued. Becoming clear to me that no one has Phoebe’s dialogue and flair for the absurdity. I guess I just… have to accept that.

summary: “we’re working on the assumption that this is a woman, late to middle age, looks like an immigrant worker, so you know, she’s...
body:
“we’re working on the assumption that this is a woman, late to middle age, looks like an immigrant worker, so you know, she’s not white–”

“what makes you think that?”

“the fact that you just interrupted me mid sentence makes me think that”

i would die for eve

summary: REVIEW: Killing Eve, S2 Ep2 - Nice and Neat
title: REVIEW: Killing Eve, S2 Ep2 - Nice and Neat
body:
REVIEW: Killing Eve, S2 Ep2 – Nice and Neat

Killing Eve continues as Eve investigates a new female assassin and Villanelle recovers from her injury while setting foot in England.

There was a tantalizing moment in this episode when we thought Villanelle and Eve would finally see each other again but it is too soonfor that fateful confrontation. Instead, we have that slightly frustrating scene of Villanelle driving off in a car, her face…

View On WordPress

summary: Not surprised about Konstantin’s return. If a character doesn’t visibly take their last breath on screen, there’s always the...
body:
Not surprised about Konstantin’s return.

If a character doesn’t visibly take their last breath on screen, there’s always the option of bringing them back (see Delphine on Orphan Black).
